profile.profileDescription: Minnesota Alliance of Local History Museums

Ställ in postens primära status typer
Valeurs de type de libellés pour les lots d'objets
Valeurs de type libellés de lieux
Valeurs de types de libellé d'emplacements de stockage

label.name_singular: To be carried by the Borrower
label.name_plural: To be carried by the Borrower

label.name_singular: To be carried by the Lender
label.name_plural: To be carried by the Lender

label.name_singular: Cushite-(Includes Oromo, Somali, Sidamo, and other East African languages)
label.name_plural: Cushite-(Includes Oromo, Somali, Sidamo, and other East African languages)

label.name: Nomenclature Category
label.description: A system of standardized classification of museum collections. Required for data sharing.

label.name: Title
label.description: The formal creator-given title for books, works of art etc. If no formal title exists, create a descriptive title.

label.name: Alternate object names
label.description: Alternate name(s) for the item. This can include spelling variations, local terms, slang etc.

label.name: Other numbers
label.description: An alternate number for the unit other than the primary object identifier number. For example: old numbering systems or Found In Collection numbers.

label.name: Description
label.description: A free text account of the physical characteristics and historical significance of the item.

label.name: Credit line
label.description: A credit line may be entered in the Accession or here. The credit line may express a memorial to a donor or relative of a donor, For example:, "Given in memory of Jane Doe." The credit line often appears on exhibit labels, for example, "Gift of Mr. and Mrs. John Doe"

label.name: Exhibition label
label.description: Exhibit Label is a description of an artifact that may differ from the catalog description of an item. This field can be used to capture labels from past exhibitions.

label.name: Notes
label.description: Additional notes or information related to the item.

label.name: Date created (Earliest-Latest)
label.description: A date or date range to denote when the item was made.

label.name: Date excavated
label.description: The date a unit was collected in the field.

label.name: Date repatriated
label.description: Date the physical custody of and legal interest in Native American cultural items were transferred to lineal descendants, culturally affiliated Indian tribes, and Native Hawaiian organizations. (https://www.nps.gov/nagpra/TRAINING/GLOSSARY.HTM)

label.name: Acquisition date
label.description: Date the grouping of objects were donated to the museum/historical society.

label.name: Accession date
label.description: Date the accession was added to the museum's collection.

label.name: Accessory
label.description: Any additional part or parts that belong with an object.

label.name: Dimensions
label.description: Enter the metric dimensions of the item or its components, such as a frame.

label.name: Height
label.description: Height of object; enter in your preferred units (eg. 10cm)

label.name: Width
label.description: Width of object; enter in your preferred units (eg. 10cm)

label.name: Depth
label.description: depth of object; enter in your preferred units (eg. 10cm)

label.name: Length
label.description: Length of object; enter in your preferred units (eg. 10cm)

label.name: Weight
label.description: Weight of object; enter in your preferred units

label.name: Diameter
label.description: Diameter of object; enter in your preferred units

label.name: Circumference
label.description: Circumference of object; enter in your preferred units

label.name: Thickness
label.description: Thickness of object; enter in your preferred units

label.name: Duration
label.description: Enter the play length of the audio or moving image file.

label.name: Count
label.description: Use the count field to record the number of items/parts/components associated with this particular catalog record.

label.name: Inscription
label.description: A description or transcription of any distinguishing or identifying physical lettering, annotations, texts, markings, or labels that are affixed, applied, stamped, written, inscribed, or attached to the work.

label.name: Signature
label.description: The form in which the artist has signed his/her name. For example: if Pablo Picasso has used only his first name as a signature on a work of art, enter "Pablo" in the Signed Name Field. >> Record the location of the artist's signature in the location field. For example "Lower right".

label.name: Signed name
label.description: This field is used to record the form in which the artist has signed his/her name. For example; if Pablo Picasso has used only his first name as a signature on a work of art, enter "Pablo" in the Signed Name field.

label.name: Signature location
label.description: Record the location of the artist's signature in this field. For example, "Lower right".

label.name: Material
label.description: List all materials found within the item.

label.name: Material (Legacy)
label.description: Materials values imported from old systems. Use the "Material" dropdown instead.

label.name: Material
label.description: List all materials found within the item.

label.name: Medium
label.description: The medium field is used to list all media from which an art object or photograph is made.

label.name: Manufacturer's Mark
label.description: Describe any maker's marks.

label.name: Primary format
label.description: Enter the primary format of the audio or moving image here.

label.name: Additional format
label.description: Enter all additional formats of the audio or moving image here.

label.name: Format notes
label.description: Addition notes regarding the format of the resource. This can include backup information.

label.name: Attached text
label.description: Notes, labels, ephemeral physically attached to the item. For example: Notes written on the back of a photo.

label.name: Technique
label.description: The way in which the fundamentals, as of an artistic work, are handled. A method or way of working with materials to create a work of art.

label.name: Used
label.description: This field may be used to record how, where, or by whom an object was used. This may be a phrase such as, "Food processing", or it may be an individual's name. In some cases, this field may record the geographic location where an artifact was used, for example, "Winter Village Site".

label.name: Condition reporting
label.description: Use this field to describe the details about the item's condition. Dating your entry allows you to keep a history of the condition of the item. Note any changes when you are performing routine maintenance, or as damage occurs.

label.name: Condition rating
label.description: Select the overall condition rating here.

label.name: Condition notes
label.description: Use the this field to describe details about the item's condition. You may keep a history of the condition of an item by dating your entries. Note any changes when you are performing routine maintenance, or as damage occurs.

label.name: Examined by
label.description: Type the name of the person who examined an item and assigned a condition value.

label.name: Date examined
label.description: Condition Date records the date upon which an item was examined and assigned a Condition.

label.name: Documentation
label.description: Upload any documentation you have here, such as handwritten condition reports.

label.name: Conservation
label.description: This field contains remarks about any conservation, preservation or treatment not covered in other fields. This may include recommendations from the conservator on care and handling of the item, frequency and methods of environmental monitoring, etc. It can also include notes on how the item was treated in the past, such as the donor having made a repair to a vase with crazy glue. If multiple condition reports have been completed and different conservators left notes, click Add Conservation Notes to duplicate the field and enter each note on its own line, being sure to mention the date and author of the notes.

label.name: Georeference
label.description: Coordinates documenting the location of the item.

label.name: Geographic Notes
label.description: Additional geographic notes regarding item.

label.name: Public Land Survey System
label.description: Enter the township, range and section information. This field is repeatable for large areas.

label.name: Location Notes
label.description: Enter any additional notes regarding the item's location.

label.name: Provenance
label.description: A detailed history of the past ownership of an item. Give information, including dates, on successive transfers of ownership and custody of the item. Ideally, the Provenance field will list the history of the item from its creation, through subsequent owners to its final transfer to your institution.

label.name: Rights
label.description: Information about rights held in and over the resource.

label.name: Rights holder
label.description: To identify the person or organisation holding or managing the rights related to the resource.

label.name: Copyright statement
label.description: Use to state copyright statements over the resource.

label.name: Publication notes
label.description: Information about past publication of the resource.

label.name: Found
label.description: An object may be found in a different location than where it was created or manufactured. This field is used to describe where an object was found. It may be a culture area such as "Navajo" or it may be a geographical location such as "Minnesota/Stevens County/Peterson Farm".

label.name: School
label.description: Refers to a specific artistic style or movement with a common origin, influence or unifying belief. For Example: Hudson River School.

label.name: Style
label.description: A distinctive manner which permits the grouping of works of art into specific categories. For example: Abstract, Composite

label.name: Culture
label.description: Name of the culture, people, or nationality from which the work originated.

label.name: Event
label.description: Event refers to a named occasion associated with artifacts, archival materials or photographs. For example, a collection may include photos, printed materials, and hats from a political convention.

label.name: Language
label.description: The language(s), script(s), and symbol systems employed in the materials being described, particularly as they may affect its use.

label.name: Number of pages
label.description: The physical extent of a document expressed in a count of the pages that form an individual collection unit; entered as a whole number.

label.name: Library of Congress number
label.description: The Library of Congress Control Number (LCCN) is a serially based system of numbering cataloging records in the Library of Congress in the United States. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Library_of_Congress_Control_Number

label.name: Getty Art and Architecture Thesarus
label.description: Select terms from the Getty Art and Architecture Thesaurus that can describe this item.

label.name: Getty Union List of Artist Names
label.description: Select names from the Getty Union List of Artist Names that can describe this item.

label.name: Library of Congress subject headings
label.description: Library of Congress Subject headings describing this object. To add a new heading simply type the first few letters of the heading and choose the desired one from the displayed list of possible matches.

label.name: Library of Congress Name Authority File
label.description: Enter authority files from the Library Of Congress that apply to this item.

label.name: Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names
label.description: Select names from the Getty Thesaurus of Geographical Names that can describe this item.

label.name: Appraisal information
label.description: Information about the past and current appraisal methods for the object.

label.name: Date of appraisal
label.description: Enter the date on which the appraisal took place.

label.name: Appraised by
label.description: Use this field to record the name of the person who last appraised the item.

label.name: Appraisal amount
label.description: Use this field to enter the value of the item at acquisition. This may be the price you paid for the item or an appraised value.

label.name: Notes
label.description: Use this field to record any additional information about the item that may have effected the appraisal.

label.name: Insurance value
label.description: Insured Value is used to record the amount of insurance coverage on the item.

label.name: Site number
label.description: Enter the name of the site from which the artifact was recovered.

label.name: Bag number
label.description: Record the original Bag Number that was assigned to the item by the field collector. This number refers to the provenance of an archaeological specimen.

label.name: Box number
label.description: Record the original Box Number that was assigned to the item by the field collector. This number refers to the provenance of an archaeological specimen.

label.name: Dating method
label.description: Record which archaeological dating method was used to date the object.

label.name: Datum
label.description: Datum describes a point, line, or surface used as a reference for mapping. Archaeological measurements are taken from a fixed point to ensure comparability of data. Use the Datum Field to record the fixed point from which measurements were taken for this item.

label.name: Feature
label.description: An archaeological feature is any definable archaeological phenomenon which is discernibly different for the surrounding deposits. Feature is often defined as material remains that cannot be transported such as fire pits, storage pits, wall foundations, and post holes.

label.name: Level
label.description: The basic vertical subdivision of an excavation unit, defined metrically, such as in 5, 10, or 20 centimeter levels. Level may also refer to natural levels of stratification within the excavation unit.

label.name: Stratum
label.description: One of several parallel layers of material arranged one on top of another.

label.name: Unit
label.description: A unit is defined as a basic area of horizontal control in an excavation; usually a test pit, trench, or a standardized square. Units are organized in a system of perpendicular lines and equally spaced points to form a rectangle which is used as a frame of locational reference on an archaeological site. many Archaeological sites are surveyed by measuring from a grid enclosing the site. It is a rectilinear system of X, Y coordinates which is established over the area to be excavated so that spatial control can be maintained.

label.name: Assemblage Zone
label.description: Bio-stratigraphic unit as defined and identified by a group of associated fossils rather than by a single index fossil.

label.name: Location Coordinates
label.description: A set of numbers and/or letters used to specify an exact horizontal spatial location at a site taken in reference to a datum point.

label.name: X Coordinate
label.description: The x co-ordinate is a measurement taken from a reference datum along the x axis of a grid square enabling the archaeologist to plot the three-dimensional position of an archaeological find and record its location from a known datum point.

label.name: Y Coordinate
label.description: The y co-ordinate is a measurement taken from a reference datum along the x axis of a grid square enabling the archaeologist to plot the three-dimensional position of an archaeological find and record its location from a known datum point.

label.name: Z Coordinate
label.description: The z co-ordinate is a measurement taken from a reference datum along the x axis of a grid square enabling the archaeologist to plot the three-dimensional position of an archaeological find and record its location from a known datum point.

label.name: Authorization date
label.description: Date that a staff member authorizes reburial or repatriation of human remains and/or associated objects, objects of cultural patrimony, unassociated funerary objects, or sacred objects.

label.name: Minimum number of individuals
label.description: Refers to the fewest possible number of people or animals in a skeletal assemblage. (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minimum_number_of_individuals)

label.name: Minnesota repatriation region
label.description: Indicates where remains or artifacts came from: Northeast, Northwest, East Central, West Central, Southeast, or Southwest county group.

label.name: Cultural Affiliation
label.description: A relationship of shared group identity which can be reasonably traced historically or prehistorically between a present day Indian tribe or Native Hawaiian organization and an identifiable earlier group.

label.name: Date of Notice in Federal Register
label.description: Date that a Notice of Inventory Completion is published by the Government Printing Office in the Federal Register.

label.name: Federal register number
label.description: Federal Register citation number. Number given by the Government Printing Office to a published Notice of Inventory Completion such as: [FR Doc No: 2011-32980]

label.name: Notice number
label.description: The initial NAGPRA Notice of Inventory submission is considered a draft. After a museum or agency submits the draft notice, a receipt of confirmation with a temporary tracking ID number is sent to the museum/agency.

label.name: Analyzed
label.description: Indicates whether any requested analysis has been completed.

label.name: Ready for repatriation
label.description: Indicates if all preparations are complete and the object(s) or remains are ready for repatriation / reburial.

label.name: Reburial location
label.description: Geographic location where the remains / and or objects were reburied. Leave blank if unknown.

label.name: Reburial date
label.description: Date that remains and / or objects were reburied.

label.name: Claimant(s)
label.description: A lineal descendant, Indian tribe, or Native Hawaiian organization who asserts a claim for cultural items pursuant to NAGPRA. (https://www.nps.gov/nagpra/TRAINING/GLOSSARY.HTM)

label.name: Handling requirements
label.description: Specific recommendations given by the lineal descendents that specify care in handling, transporting, and restricting access to collections they are culturally affiliated with.

label.name: Repatriation notes
label.description: Any notes pertaining to circumstances of repatriation / reburial. If place of reburial is unknown for example, a note can explain why it is not recorded.

label.name: Life Stage
label.description: The life stage of the specimen at the time of its death. For example: Juvenile, larval, adult etc.

label.name: Habitat
label.description: Habitat is used to record the area or type of environment in which a biological specimen lives or occurs.

label.name: Sex of Specimen
label.description: Use the sex field to record the sex of the biological specimen; male, female, hermaphrodite, or unknown.

label.name: Elements
label.description: Elements refers to the separate bones present in a biological sample. For example; a skeletal specimen may not contain all the elements of the skeleton. Use this field to record the elements that are present.

label.name: Kingdom
label.description: Kingdom is the highest taxonomic classification into which organisms are grouped, based on fundamental similarities and common ancestry.

label.name: Phylum
label.description: Phylum is a primary division of a kingdom, as of the animal kingdom, ranking above class in taxonomic classification.

label.name: Class
label.description: Class is a taxonomic category ranking below a phylum and above an order.

label.name: Order
label.description: Order is a taxonomic category of organisms ranking above a family and below a class.

label.name: Family
label.description: Family is a taxonomic category of related organisms ranking below an order and above a genus.

label.name: Sub-Family
label.description: Sub-Family is a taxonomic category of related organisms ranking between family and genus.

label.name: Genus
label.description: Genus is the taxonomic category ranking below family and above species and generally consisting of a group of species exhibiting similar characteristics.

label.name: Species
label.description: This field appears on the Natural History section of the objects catalog screen. Enter the name of the species.

label.name: Color
label.description: Color obtained from the Munsell Color System.

label.name: Chemical Composition
label.description: Chemical composition reflects the number of different atoms making up a molecule. For example: the chemical formula for quartz is SiO2, which shows that each molecule consists of one atom of silica (Si) bonded to two atoms of oxygen (O2).

label.name: Crystal System
label.description: The crystal shape is an important clue to the identification of a particular mineral. The crystal system is based on the number of axes of symmetry developed. An axis is an imaginary line running through the crystal around which it can be turned to produce the same appearance from more than one side.

label.name: Formation
label.description: The fundamental lithostratigraphic unit, a thickness of, outcropping of, body of rock and soil associated with defined and identifiable characteristics, with a deposition consistent with a certain geologic time and/ or sequence of events, each geologic formation has a different total aspect of life from that above or below.

label.name: Fossils
label.description: Use this field to enter the type of fossils that are present in a rock specimen.

label.name: Fracture/Cleavage
label.description: Record the nature of the surface left behind when a piece of mineral is broken. Possible entries include "Conchoidal" or "Uneven".

label.name: Grain Size
label.description: Grain size is an indicator of how a rock was formed and its composition. This field is used to record the crain size of the specimen.

label.name: Hardness
label.description: Hardness is the property of resisting abrasion or scratching. It is measured by the MOH table of hardness. 1 is the softest and 10 is the hardest.

label.name: Lithology
label.description: 1. A lateral, mappable subdivision of a designated stratigraphic unit, distinguished from adjacent subdivisions on the basis of lithology. 2. The rock record of any sedimentary environment.

label.name: Luster
label.description: The fresh surface of a mineral will reflect light in a characteristic way. The different lusters are defined by means of comparison with the luster of everyday objects.

label.name: Occurrence
label.description: Describe the geological conditions under which a rock or mineral is formed. For example, "olivine forms only in basic igneous rocks"

label.name: Pressure
label.description: The process by which rocks are altered in composition, texture, or internal structure by extreme heat, pressure, and the introduction of new chemical substances. Indicate the level of pressure present when the rock specimen was formed.

label.name: Specific Gravity
label.description: Specific Gravity is the weight of a mineral compared with the weight of an equal volume of water.

label.name: Streak
label.description: The diagnostic mark left by a mineral as it is scratched across a hard rough surface.

label.name: Stage
label.description: A subdivision in the classification of stratified rocks, ranking just below a series and representing rock formed during a chronological age.

label.name: Surface Process
label.description: Changes in the surface of a rock or mineral due to environmental processes. For example: Weathering, Stream action, Marine action, Glacier action, Wind action.

label.name: Temperature
label.description: The temperature field is used to record, in a general way, the temperature at which a metamorphic rock was formed. Metamorphic rock is changed due to extreme conditions of pressure and temperature. Different minerals crystallize at different temperatures in metamorphic aureoles (The area surrounding the igneous intrusion near a lava flow), therefore the mineralogy of a rock close to the intrusion will be different from that farther away.

label.name: Varieties
label.description: Record any variation of the mineral that may occur. For example:quartz occurs in various colors due to the inclusion of mineral impurities. These may be recorded, separated by commas: rock crystal, milky quartz, smoky quartz, amethyst.

label.name: Type
label.description: These are common rock type names (limestone, granite, slate, gabbro)

label.name: Classification
label.description: Geologists classify rocks in three groups, according to the major Earth processes that formed them. The three rock groups are igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic.

label.name: Origin
label.description: Location rock originated from e.g. Crystal Cave Spring valley, WI.

label.name: Texture
label.description: Texture refers to the crystallinity and granularity of igneous and crystalline metamorphic rocks.

label.name: Era
label.description: The longest division of geologic time, made up of one or more periods.

label.name: Period
label.description: A unit of time, longer than an epoch and shorter than an era.

label.name: Epoch
label.description: A unit of time that is a division of a period.

label.name: Image Caption
label.description: Enter a caption for the image.

label.name: Biography
label.description: Narrative biography for entity. This is the primary text used to document the entity.

label.name: Nationality
label.description: National or cultural affiliation of the person or corporate body.

label.name: Birthplace
label.description: Enter the birthplace of the entity.

label.name: Place of Death
label.description: Enter the place of death of the entity.

label.name: Life dates
label.description: Enter the life dates for the individual, expressed as a year range, such as 1915-1960. If the person is still living, use ? as the end date. If only the death year is known use ? as the birth year.

label.name: Founding Dates
label.description: Enter the founding date of the corporate body.

label.name: Gender
label.description: Enter the gender of the individual.

label.name: Loan term
label.description: Dates for when loan is to be at or away from the museum.

label.name: Valuation
label.description: What the artifact is valued.

label.name: Transportation
label.description: How will the artifact be transported between institutions.

label.name: Condition upon return
label.description: Condition report after artifact arrives at its destination.

label.name: Condition upon arrival
label.description: Condition report after artifact arrives at its destination.

label.name: Instructions
label.description: Enter any instructions regarding the loan..

label.name: Restrictions
label.description: Donor imposed limits on the use of this item.

label.name: Loan in date
label.description: When the artifact is brought to the museum.

label.name: Loan out date
label.description: When the artifact is returned to museum.

label.name: Loan conditions
label.description: A statement of the conditions on a loan.

label.name: Loan note
label.description: General information about the loan.

label.name: Loan purpose
label.description: What you are loaning or borrowing the artifact for, usually exhibit or research purposes.

label.name: Price
label.description: Purchase price the museum paid for the artifact.

label.name: Deed of gift sent
label.description: Date Deed of Gift sent to the donor.

label.name: Deed of gift signed
label.description: Date Deed of Gift signed by the donor.

label.name: Thank you note sent
label.description: Date the Thank You letter to the donor was sent.

settings.setting:
The items listed below are left in the custody of the [INSTITUTION] to be considered for donation:

The [INSTNAME] reserves the right to keep, lend or otherwise dispose of the material.

I own the items described below and desire to give said items to the museum. I do hereby irrevocably and unconditionally give and transfer to the museum all right, title, and interest, including all copyright, trademark, and related interest, in and to the following described property. It is understood that I hereby bind myself, my heirs, executors and administrators. Possible uses of disposed material include educational, teaching or prop collections or sold to benefit the collections. I acknowledge that because of the policy of changing exhibitions, the [INSTITUTION] has not promised, and is not obligated, to exhibit the property.

    • Please check here if the item(s) are only given to be considered for acquisition into the collection. If not accepted into the collection, the donor shall be notified and will 90 days to pick up the item(s) or make other arrangements for disposal. After 90 days the item(s) will become the property of the museum.

On behalf of the Officers and Directors of the [INSTITUTION], the community, and visiting researchers, I would like to thank you for your recent gift to the museum. No goods or services were exchanged for this donation.

Long-term care and preservation of artifacts does not happen without resources. It costs us approximately $40 in supplies, staff time, and building costs to keep an average archival box on the shelf for one year. Any financial support that you are able to provide towards the preservation of your donation would be greatly appreciated.

If you have any more information you would like to add about the history of the item(s) included in this donation, please let me know and we will add it to our records.

Again, thank you for your generous gift.

label.name: Thank you letter - Needs deed of gift (body text)

settings.setting:
On behalf of the Officers and Directors of the [INSTITUTION], the community, and visiting researchers, I would like to thank you for your recent gift to the museum. No goods or services were exchanged for this donation.

In order to complete the donation, please sign both copies of the enclosed Deed of Gift. Please return the original in the self-addressed, stamped envelope enclosed. You may retain the copy for your records.

Long-term care and preservation of artifacts does not happen without resources. It costs us approximately $40 in supplies, staff time, and building costs to keep an average archival box on the shelf for one year. Any financial support that you are able to provide towards the preservation of your donation would be greatly appreciated.

If you have any more information you would like to add about the history of the item(s) included in this donation, please let me know and we will add it to our records.

Again, thank you for your generous gift.

label.name: Begin and End Dates
label.description: Begin and end dates of the exhibition. If the exhibition is open ended, the end dates can be added later.

label.name: Location
label.description: The location of the exhibition.

label.name: Date
label.description: This element identifies and records the date(s) that pertain to the creation, assembly, accumulation, and/or maintenance and use of the materials being described.

label.name: Extent
label.description: This element indicates the extent and the physical nature of the materials being described.

label.name: Administrative/Biographical History Element
label.description: A description of the context in which the materials being described were created, assembled, and/or maintained is as important as the description of the materials themselves

label.name: Scope and Content
label.description: This element provides information about the nature of the materials and activities reflected in the unit being described to enable users to judge its potential relevance.

label.name: System of Arrangement
label.description: This element identifies the various aggregations of archival materials, their relationships, or the sequence of documents within them.

label.name: Conditions Governing Access
label.description: This element provides information about access restrictions due to the nature of the information in the materials being described, such as those imposed by the donor, by the repository, or by statutory/regulatory requirements.

label.name: Physical Access
label.description: This element provides information about access restrictions due to any physical characteristics or storage locations that limit, restrict, delay, or otherwise affect access to the materials being described.

label.name: Technical Access
label.description: This element provides information about access restrictions due to any technical requirements restrict or otherwise affect access to the materials being described, such as equipment or specific hardware/software required for use.

label.name: Conditions Governing Reproduction
label.description: This element identifies any restrictions on reproduction due to copyright or other reasons, as well as restrictions on further use of the materials being described, such as publication after access has been provided.

label.name: Languages and Scripts on the Material
label.description: This element identifies the language(s), script(s), and symbol systems employed in the materials being described, particularly as they may affect its use.

label.name: Other Finding Aids
label.description: This element identifies any other finding aids to the materials being described particularly if they are available to the user, and provides information about the form and content of those finding aids.

label.name: Existence and Location of Originals
label.description: This element indicates the existence, location, and availability of originals when the materials being described consist of copies, and the originals are not held by the repository

label.name: Existence and Location of Copies
label.description: This element indicates the existence, location, and availability of copies or other reproductions of the materials being described when they are available for use in an institution, or for loan or purchase, or available electronically. Do not mention copies in private hands or copies made for personal use.

label.name: Publication Note
label.description: This element identifies any publications that are about or are based on the use, study, or analysis of the materials being described.

label.name: Processing Information
label.description: Provide information about actions of the archivist, custodians, or creators of the records or conventions in the finding aid that may have an impact on a researcher’s interpretation of the records or understanding of the information provided in the finding aid. Actions and conventions include but are not limited to reconstruction of provenance, maintenance, reconstruction, or alteration of original order, devising titles for materials, weeding, and maintenance or provision of control numbers or container numbers.

label.name: Preferred Citation
label.description: Indicate the preferred style for the citation of the unit being described.

label.name: Custodial History
label.description: This element provides information on changes of ownership or custody of the material being described, from the time it left the possession of the creator until it was acquired by the repository that is significant for its authenticity, integrity, and interpretation.

label.name: Immediate Source of Acquisition
label.description: Record information about changes of ownership or custody of the materials being described that do not involve direct acquisition by the repository and that are significant for its authenticity, integrity, and interpretation in the Custodial History Element.

label.name: Appraisal, Destruction, and Scheduling Information
label.description: This element provides information about the rationale for appraisal decisions, destruction actions, and disposition schedules that are relevant to the understanding and use of the materials being described.

label.name: Accruals
label.description: This element informs the user of anticipated additions to the unit being described. An accrual is an acquisition of archival materials additional to that already in the custody of the repository.

label.name: General notes
label.description: Record, as needed, information not accommodated by any of the defined elements of description.

label.name: Conservation notes
label.description: Describe any specific conservation treatment.

label.name: Related Archival Materials
label.description: This element indicates the existence and location of archival materials that are closely related to the materials being described by provenance, sphere of activity, or subject matter, either in the same repository, in other repositories, or elsewhere.

label.name: Repository
label.description: This element identifies the name and location of the repository that hold the materials being described.

label.name: Recommended for deaccessioning
label.description: Click the box if you would like to put the artifact on a list for deaccession consideration.

label.name: Geonames
label.description: Select appropriate terms from the GeoNames to link places to this item. You can easily add terms at http://www.geonames.org/.

label.name: Location Authorized by
label.description: Enter the name of the person responsible for authorizing the movement of an item from its home location to a temporary location.

label.name: Location by
label.description: Enter the name of the person who moved the item to the temporary location.

label.name: Location Notes
label.description: The Location Notes field is used to record any additional information about the location.

label.name: Location Reason
label.description: The Location Reason field is used to record the reason for moving an item to a location.

label.name: Location Until
label.description: The Location Until field is used to record the date upon which an item is expected to return from the location to its permanent location.

settings.setting:
Enter the unique object number assigned to the item.
The ideal format is: the the four digit year (YYYY), then the accession lot number, then the item number. For example:  1986.0001.0034 Do not enter colons, commas, semicolons or symbols as part of an Accession Number. You may use different institutional numbering systems as necessary.
You may also assign a temporary ""Found in Collection"" number.

Enter the unique accession number assigned to the incoming lot of items. The ideal format is: the four digit year the lot was accepted (YYYY), then the accession lot number. 
Some institutions start at 1 each new year, others just continue lot numbers in sequence, regardless of the year. Do not enter colons, commas, semicolons or symbols as part of an Accession Number. You may use different institutional numbering systems as necessary.
You may also wish to assign temporary custody numbers to unaccessioned donations and update once the accession is official.

A text descriptio​n of the contents of the Accession Lot, used for administra​tive, identifica​tion, and reporting purposes. The information in this open text field will appear as the title of the accession when searching accession records. You may wish to use keywords to help you recognize the accession.

Select the name of the item from the Object Term (fourth level) Nomenclature drop down list. Always focus on the item’s original intended use.
If there is more than one name for the item, use the Alternative Object Name field to record other terms. Do not add qualifying data or extra details this field.

Enter a numeric date or date range to denote when the object was made. For archival documents such as diaries or ledgers, enter the date range for when the document was edited. If the year alone is not precise enough, record a more precise date, such as May 13, 1942. If a date is not known, determine a possible date range based on available information, such as 1900 to 1970. Qualifying terms can be used: Circa = approximate date, determined by researching other sources.

Enter any name variations for the item, such as local slang terms, colloquialisms, alternate spellings, etc.
If multiple alternatives exist, click Add Name to duplicate the field and enter each one on its own line. Attributed or uncertain alternate names should be followed by a space and ?

Enter the greatest overall metric dimensions of the object using the applicable fields. Enter the numerical value with the appropriate metric unit, i.e. 20.3 cm. For objects with parts, record the overall dimensions of the object assembled. Measurements for significant parts (important for research or storage purposes) should be recorded under Dimension Remarks and specifically identified with the part number, for example: The print (part A) was measured without being removed from the frame (part B).

Enter the unique accession number assigned to the incoming lot of items. The ideal format is: the four digit year the lot was accepted (YYYY), then the accession lot number. 
Some institutions start at 1 each new year, others just continue lot numbers in sequence, regardless of the year. Do not enter colons, commas, semicolons or symbols as part of an Accession Number. You may use different institutional numbering systems as necessary.

Formal Titles are creator-given titles found on books, paintings, CD's, songs, and other works of art. If the item has a formal title, enter it as written with no quotation marks or other punctuation.
If no formal title exists, you should create a descriptive title that contains relevant specific information about the item. For information on how to create descriptive titles for photographs and other resources see Minnesota Digital Library Guidelines. https://mndigital.org/standards-best-practices/minnesota-reflections-metadata-entry-guidelines

Map any locations related to the object, such as where a photograph was taken or where an object was made. Pinpoint a location by typing the place name in the search bar. Hit enter or click the magnifying glass icon and the map will reposition to the location and insert a dot. For street level locations, zoom in to make sure the dot was put in the right spot. If necessary, move the dot by clicking and dragging it to the correct location. You can also map an area, such as an archaeological site, property boundaries, etc. To do this, search for your location and then select one of the outline tools. Click to create boundary points and draw the desired area. Double-click to stop drawing, and save the record.
Select all relevant materials from the drop down list. The list can be customized through Manage > Lists and Vocabularies.

Provide a physical description of the item to create an accurate picture of it with words.
You can also use this field to record information about the people, places, events and themes related to the item. The description should be written in complete sentences. All information that is in the Description and is required for retrieval should also be indexed in appropriate fields elsewhere in the record. If the item has parts, be sure to include the letter or number designation for that part at the beginning of its description.

Select appropriate locations from the GeoNames list to link those locations to this item. You can easily add locations at http://www.geonames.org/.
Minnesota Digital Library requires GeoNames for their entries.
Once you select locations and save, you will see a link in Collective Access that will bring you to the GeoNames website with maps and more information about the specific location.
Select keywords from the hierarchy that will help you find this record.

This field draws from the exhibition list in the database, so once you begin typing an exhibition name the system will generate suggestions from which to choose. If no exhibition record has been created, go to New – Exhibition, and create a record for the exhibition. The item can then be linked as being part of the exhibition.

This field draws from the loans list in the database, so once you begin typing a loan number, the system will generate suggestions from which to choose. If no loan record has been created, go to New – Loan, and create a record for the loan. The item can then be linked as being part of the loan.
This field identifies the culture associated with the object based on its social/geographic origin. Open text field.

This field indicates the building, room, cabinet etc. where the item is permanently located or currently stored. Storage Locations are pre-set in the database as a hierarchy. Click on the arrow beside ‘Storage Location’ and then click on the appropriate building (Example: Emily Carr House), then click on the appropriate room (Example: Display Room), etc. You can be as specific as you'd like by adding cabinets, shelves and drawers. If the required building, room, cabinet is not in the pre-set entries, add them under NEW - STORAGE LOCATION.

This field is for related places. Places can include but are not limited to: cities, villages, buildings, parks, and sites. Places are pre-set in the database as a hierarchy. If the required place is not in the pre-set entries, add them under NEW - PLACES.

This field is used to describe the condition of an item. Use the notes field to describe the details about the item's condition. You may keep a history of the condition of the item by creating separate entries with dates. Note any changes when you are performing routine maintenance, or as damage occurs.
Upload any documentation you have, such as handwritten condition reports.
Select the condition rating from the drop down list which best describes the overall condition of the object at the time of acquisition. Excellent – no damage/deterioration Very Good – normal signs of wear Good – slight damage/deterioration, dirty Fair – problems more severe, handling and exhibit concerns Poor – unstable, difficult handling, needs attention Very Poor – severe deterioration, should not be handled or used for exhibits Unknown – the current condition of the object is unknown

This field is used to group items based on their original use and is a preset drop down menu. Select the most appropriate name from the fourth level "object term" or lower from the drop-down list. Alternately, you can type into the search box and select the appropriate sub-classification.
If an object had multiple uses and fits more than one Object Term, the field can be duplicated and the appropriate information selected from the dropdown menu by clicking on Add Category. Do not enter all three levels of Category, Classification and Sub-Classification. The drop down menu is a hierarchy and the system understands which Category and Classification apply once the Object Term has been selected.

Use this field to link individuals and organizations to the item or record. Creators, past owners, donors, subjects, are all entities that should be connected to the item. Begin typing the name into the search box and select from the list. If the person or organization is not on the list, you can quick add an entity from here, or go to NEW>Entity from the menu at the top of the page.
Select the relationship of the individual or organization to the object.

Items from your collection linked to this item or record. For example, objects connected to a loan or exhibit. Or a photograph in your collection that depicts a three-dimensional object in your collection.
Use this field to link the Collection to the item or record.
Summary of the loan. This information will appear when you search for loans.
A unique alphanumeric identifier for this loan.
The date when the loan was authorized.

label.name: Editeur de configuration de types de relation
Editeur de configuration de formulaires de recherche

settings.setting: A unique alphanumeric identifier for this item.
A unique alphanumeric identifier for the related accession / lot record. This will auto fill if you are adding items/resources from the accession record.
Primary standardized name of the item, focusing on the item's original intended use.
Individuals and organizations linked to this item or record.
The building, room, cabinet etc. where the item is permanently located or currently stored. Select from the hierarchy.
This field will automatically populate as related locations and exhibitions are updated.
A list of exhibitions that have included this item, or related to this entity.
A list of loans that have included this item or related to this entity.

Items from your collection linked to this item or record. For example, objects connected to a loan or exhibit. Or a photograph in your collection that depicts a three-dimensional object in your collection.
Keywords used to tag an item.
Use this field to add photographs of the item. Representations can also include audio, video and documents.

"This field is for related places. Places can include but are not limited to: cities, villages, buildings, parks, and sites. Places are pre-set in the database as a hierarchy. If the required place is not in the pre-set entries, add them under NEW - PLACES. "

Indian Tribe Official: The principal leader of an Indian Tribe or Native Hawaiian organization or the individual officially designated by the governing body of an Indian tribe or Native Hawaiian organization or as otherwise provided by tribal code, policy, or established procedure as responsible for matters relating to these regulations (43 CFR 10). [43 CFR 10.2 (b)(4)] The NAGPRA Contact may also be the Tribe's THPO Officer.
Unique alphanumeric identifier for this place.
A unique alphanumeric identifier for this exhibition.
Summary of the exhibition. This information will appear when you search for exhibitions.
An account of the exhibition. All information that is in the Description and is required for retrieval should also be indexed in appropriate fields elsewhere in the record.
A unique alphanumeric identifier for this archival collection.
The title of the collection. This information will appear when you search for collections.

Use this field to link to individuals and organizations responsible for the creation of this collection. Begin typing the name into the search box and select from the list. If the person or organization is not on the list, you can quick add an entity from here, or go to NEW>Entity from the menu at the top of the page.
Select the relationship of the individual or organization to the collection before you save.

A text descriptio​n of the contents of the Accession Lot, used for administra​tive, identifica​tion, and reporting purposes. The information in this open text field will appear as the title of the accession when searching accession records. You may wish to use keywords to help you recognize the accession.
A unique alphanumeric identifier for the related accession / lot record.
Indicate accession/collection status of a lot. For example: accessioned, pending accession, non-accessioned item, pending acquisition.

Use this field to record the last legal owner prior to acquisition by the museum, i.e. the person who signed over legal title of the object to the museum. Contact information, birth & death dates, notes etc are entered onto the entity form according to the fields provided. For organizations, enter the name of the company or institution in the Donor field and in the Note section, record who signed for the gift on behalf of the organization. For donations of jointly-owned property (i.e. siblings donating an object from their parents’ estate), click the Add relationship button to duplicate the field and enter each individual separately.
Use this field to upload deeds of gift and other documents pertaining to this accession.

role.name: Administrators
role.description: Confers actions needed by those administering the system

role.name: Cataloguers
role.description: Confers actions needed by those editing catalogue entries

role.name: Researcher
role.description: Allows users to only search and view - but not edit - catalogue entries

role.name: User content moderator
role.description: Allows users to moderate user generated tags and comments

group.name: Cataloguers
group.description: Users who can add and edit catalogue entries

settings.setting: <ifdef code="ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_width|ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_height|ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_length|ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_depth"></ifdef> ^ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_length<ifdef code="ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_length"> L x</ifdef> ^ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_width<ifdef code="ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_width"> W x</ifdef> ^ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_height<ifdef code="ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_height"> H x</ifdef> ^ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_depth<ifdef code="ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_depth"> D</ifdef>

<ifdef code="ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_width|ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_height|ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_length|ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_depth"></ifdef> ^ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_length<ifdef code="ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_length"> L x</ifdef> ^ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_width<ifdef code="ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_width"> W x</ifdef> ^ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_height<ifdef code="ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_height"> H x</ifdef> ^ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_depth<ifdef code="ca_objects.dimensions.dimensions_depth"> D</ifdef>

label.name: Thank you - needs deed of gift
